hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
deepseek-r1-0528-fireworks_translation:
Puali'i seized the razor and went until he reached the middle where Nāmakaokapāo'o was broiling his four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the other children saw, ran away, and stood at a distant place out of fear for Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Hey! This razor in my hand will cut off your head today; when your head is severed, it will be baked with the sweet potatoes and I will eat first; then it will be free." Nāmakaokapāo'o paid no attention to these words of Puali'i. Then Puali'i said it again, that second time. As Puali'i prepared to cut Nāmakaokapāo'o with the razor, Nāmakaokapāo'o recited his death prayer against Puali'i. The prayer went thus:
"Greatly beloved are the eyes of my little pāoʻo [fish],
As they shrivel and cling stubbornly,
Perhaps to consume, perhaps to leave aside,
Yet perhaps to leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,
This is my dear companion,
Nāmakaokaiʻa, the paramount chief of Hawaiʻi,
To flee, to flee while the weakling merely heaves a sigh,
For warriors had spears,
And spears had piercing tips,
They died by Nāmakaokapāoʻo."
raw_response:
<translation>
Puali'i seized the razor and went until he reached the middle where Nāmakaokapāo'o was broiling his four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the other children saw, ran away, and stood at a distant place out of fear for Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Hey! This razor in my hand will cut off your head today; when your head is severed, it will be baked with the sweet potatoes and I will eat first; then it will be free." Nāmakaokapāo'o paid no attention to these words of Puali'i. Then Puali'i said it again, that second time. As Puali'i prepared to cut Nāmakaokapāo'o with the razor, Nāmakaokapāo'o recited his death prayer against Puali'i. The prayer went thus:
"Greatly beloved are the eyes of my little pāoʻo [fish],
As they shrivel and cling stubbornly,
Perhaps to consume, perhaps to leave aside,
Yet perhaps to leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,
That is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,
This is my dear companion,
Nāmakaokaiʻa, the paramount chief of Hawaiʻi,
To flee, to flee while the weakling merely heaves a sigh,
For warriors had spears,
And spears had piercing tips,
They died by Nāmakaokapāoʻo."
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 7:**
• This passage depicts the climactic confrontation between Pualiʻi and Nāmakaokapāoʻo, revealing critical tensions around *kapu* (sacred law), chiefly agency, and cultural transformation:
    – The *koʻilipi* (razor) functions as both physical weapon and symbolic ritual tool, recalling instances where aliʻi priests employed human sacrifice to enforce the 'Ai kapu system. Pualiʻi's explicit ritual language (*"kālua me ka 'uala"* – "baked with sweet potato," *"'ai iho aʻu ma mua, a laila noa"* – "I eat first to free it from taboo") adapts sacrificial protocol to personal vendetta, signifying the corruption of traditional kapu;
    – Nāmakaokapāoʻo's disregard for the threats (*"ʻaʻohe hoʻolohe"*) embodies *mana koʻikoʻi* (supernatural sovereignty), recalling accounts of god-born heroes (e.g., Kamehameha) whose divine protections manifested under threat (Reference: S.M. Kamakau, *Ruling Chiefs of Hawaiʻi*);

• The *pule make* (death prayer) is rich with metaphysical symbolism:
    – *Aloha wale ka maka o aʻu wahi pāoʻo*: Connects his name's *maka* (eyes) to *pāoʻo* – a tidal pool fish known for regenerative resilience, reflecting the boy as both vulnerable and indestructible (Footnote: Mary Kawena Pukui noted *pāoʻo* symbolizes regeneration in chants);
    – Name sequences carry esoteric meaning:
        *Nā-kukuiʻai-maka-o-ka-lani*: "The-candlenut-lighting-up-eyeballs-of-the-heavens" – evokes celestial vision.
        *Nā-maka-o-Kaiʻa*: "Eyes-that-belong-to-Kaiʻa" – references an ancient sea spirit, positioning the boy as universal protector;
    – Chant structure follows traditional *kaona* (layered meaning) with dual interpretations:
        – Literal: Nāmakaokapāoʻo describes sacrificial defeat (*"hapupuʻu...hāpāpaʻa"* = shriveled/vulnerable).
        – Symbolic: Power inversion where the oppressed becomes victor (*"Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāoʻo"*);
    – Historical parallel: Lines *"ʻo ka ihe nō me ka pahu"* (spears with points) parallels Kamehameha's chant when unifying Hawaiʻi, identifying Nāmakaokapāoʻo as a timeless unifier figure;

• Core cultural conflict manifests through contrasting actions:
    – Pualiʻi represents decaying 'Ai kapu: Personalizes sacrificial ritual into vengeance ritual (abusing traditional protocol), using an imported *koʻilipi* while attacking native resources (ʻuala);
    – Nāmakaokapāoʻo embodies emergent Hawaiian nationalism: Transcends victimhood through prophetic *pule*, repurposing tradition for self-defense. His chanted *"Heʻe lā!"* (flee!) commands both natural withdrawal (like tides) and martial dominance (like ʻihe warriors);

• Children fleeing (*"holo akula...ma kahi lōʻihi"*) marks social collapse, contrasting earlier accounts about community obligation to receive strangers ('Example 2'). Their abandonment reflects the story's deeper critique: When leaders betray *aloha ʻāina* (earth stewardship), societal bonds disintegrate.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
